did.abstract: The Music Center of Los Angeles County, a seven-acre performing arts complex in downtown Los Angeles, opened when the Dorothy Chandler Pavilion raised its curtain for the first time on December 6, 1964. The Ahmanson Theatre and Mark Taper Forum followed in April 1967. The complex expanded to eleven acres on October 24, 2003, when the Walt Disney Concert Hall opened, which includes the Roy and Edna Disney/CalArts Theater and the W.M. Keck Foundation Children's Amphitheatre. The Music Center records range from 1732-2018 and contain the files of the Music Center Operating Company, Otto Rothschild, the Los Angeles Philharmonic Orchestra, the Hollywood Bowl, the Los Angeles Civic Light Opera, the Dorothy Chandler Pavilion, the Center Theatre Group, fundraising organizations, the Music Center Education Division, the Walt Disney Concert Hall, and the Music Center Reference Library as well as memorabilia and ephemera.

It is the responsibility of the researcher to determine who holds the copyright and pursue the copyright owner or his or her heir for permission to publish where The UC Regents do not hold the copyright.

custodhist.head: Custodial History
custodhist.p: Mr. Joel Pritkin joined the staff of The Music Center Operating Company on September 8, 1970 as the Archivist for the Music Center. He was responsible for collecting, evaluating, systematizing, preserving, and making available for reference Music Center public records and documents of historical significance. Prior to Pritkin's arrival, Kenn Randall and Norman Macdonald, two of the Music Center's House Managers initiated the archives out of two small storage rooms in the Ahmanson Theatre. Randall and Macdonald undertook to collect historical items from the previous five years of the Center's existence. Because up until that time there was no plan to systematically retain these things, many were lost or scattered throughout the offices and even outside of the Music Center complex. Music Center chief administrator Bill Severns arranged for the purchase of the Raymond F. Barnes collection through the estate. This collection forms a nucleus of reference books and biographies, as well as historical items (mainly programs) covering much of the past of the Music Center and its Resident Groups, along with a wide selection of other theatres around the world. Shortly after Pritkin's hire, the Archives office was relocated to two rooms in the Ahmanson Annex where Pritkin was joined by Archives assistants James Davis and Larry Phillips. Pritkin's role as curator of the Music Center Archives continued until the arrival of Archivist Molly Paradiso circa 1990. Paradiso was joined by Julio Cesar Gonzalez circa 1993. Gonzalez worked as the Music Center Archivist for over two decades until his retirement on September 1, 2017.

Sources: Music Center Operating Company Bulletin, September 8, 1970., Paradiso, Molly. Music Center Operating Company memo, April 12, 1990., Paradiso, Molly, and Julio Gonzalez. Music Center Operating Company memo, July 1, 1993., and The Top O' The Mall IV, no. 1 (January 1971).

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Collections are processed to a variety of levels depending on the work necessary to make them usable, their perceived user interest and research value, availability of staff and resources, and competing priorities. Library Special Collections provides a standard level of preservation and access for all collections and, when time and resources permit, conducts more intensive processing. These materials have been arranged and described according to national and local standards and best practices.
Processed by Kelly Besser, Genie Guerard and Octavio Olvera in 2018, with additional assistance from Tess Livesley-O'Neill in 2020.
The Music Center records were transferred to UCLA Library Special Collections in January 2018.

We are committed to providing ethical, inclusive, and anti-racist description of the materials we steward, and to remediating existing description of our materials that contains language that may be offensive or cause harm. We invite you to submit feedback about how our collections are described, and how they could be described more accurately, by filling out the form located on our website: Report Potentially Offensive Description in Library Special Collections.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The Music Center of Los Angeles County, a seven-acre performing arts complex in downtown Los Angeles, opened when the Dorothy Chandler Pavilion raised its curtain for the first time on December 6, 1964. The Ahmanson Theatre and Mark Taper Forum followed in April 1967. The complex expanded to eleven acres on October 24, 2003, when the Walt Disney Concert Hall opened, which includes the Roy and Edna Disney/CalArts Theater and the W.M. Keck Foundation Children's Amphitheatre.

Proposals for a performing arts center in Los Angeles had produced years of unsuccessful discussion and compromise between private citizens, County government, and downtown business organizations. The Music Center's story began with the Southern California Symphony Association's search for a permanent home for the Los Angeles Philharmonic Orchestra.

In 1955, the Board of Supervisors appointed Dorothy Chandler, wife of Los Angeles Times publisher Norman Chandler, as chairperson of a civic committee to promote a performing arts facility for the County of Los Angeles. After many years of negotiation, a County site was designated in downtown's Bunker Hill district with 34.5 million dollars needed for construction. With Dorothy Chandler leading the drive, the Music Center Building Fund of the Southern California Symphony Association was established. Operating out of her home with the help of hundreds of volunteers, 20 million dollars was raised by donations from the business community and private citizens.

A contract between the County and The Music Center Lease Company was then established to build the facility on County-owned property. The remaining balance of 14.5 million dollars was raised by creating a land leaseback arrangement using mortgage revenue bonds.

The Music Center Operating Company (MCOC) was formed in 1961 to oversee the construction and to manage the Music Center complex. The MCOC handled the administration and operation of the Center. Its responsibilities ranged from management of theatre, stage, and box office operations; supervision of a restaurant and concessions; and providing the information center for the complex. The MCOC licensed the use of the three theatres to both long- and short term-tenants. Long-term producing organizations, also known as resident companies, had the first choice of the available time in the theatres. The resident companies included the Los Angeles Philharmonic Orchestra, the Center Theatre Group, the Los Angeles Opera, the Joffrey Ballet, and the Master Chorale.

Source: The Music Center of Los Angeles County History and Description document, Box 402, Folder 11, Music Center records (Collection 3261). UCLA Library Special Collections, Charles E. Young Research Library, University of California, Los Angeles.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Music Center records range from 1732-2018 and contain the files of the Music Center Operating Company, photographer Otto Rothschild, the Los Angeles Philharmonic Orchestra, the Hollywood Bowl, the Los Angeles Civic Light Opera, the Dorothy Chandler Pavilion, the Center Theatre Group, fundraising organizations, the Music Center Education Division, the Walt Disney Concert Hall, and the Music Center Reference Library, as well as memorabilia and ephemera.

The Music Center records also contain the following collections: the Dorothy Chandler collection of awards and memorabilia, the Otto Rothschild photographs collection, the Marion Burke collection, the Edwin Lester Los Angeles Civic Light Opera photographic collection, the Pat Martin Opera collection, the Pilgrimage Play Theatre records, the George Zoritch collection of Playbill Magazine, the Kenn Randall collection of theatre programs, the Charles Coburn collection of sheet music, the Raymond Barnes collection of theatre programs, Mrs. Leiland A. Irish collection of Los Angeles theatre history, and the Olga Rosenthal collection of performing arts ephemera.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This collection has been arranged in the following series based on the existing order of the records:
Series 1: Music Center Operating Company files, 1949-2017
Series 3: Los Angeles Philharmonic Orchestra files, 1909-2010
Series 5: Los Angeles Civic Light Opera files, 1935-1998
Series 9: Music Center Education Division files, 1970-2014
Series 10: Walt Disney Concert Hall files, 1974-2012
Series 12: Music Center memorabilia and ephemera, 1919-2018

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Materials
separatedmaterial.p: The Master Chorale Chief Executive Officer decided to retain their records. All Master Chorale records were transferred to Carol Zamora of the Music Center in 2018 for return to the Master Chorale.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The Music Center Operating Company (MCOC) was formed July 25, 1961, to manage and operate the facilities known as the Music Center of Los Angeles County on behalf of the County of Los Angeles. Its responsibilities ranged from the management of theatre, stage, and box office operations to supervision of a restaurant and concessions. The MCOC licensed the use of the theatres to both long-term tenants, whose offices are located within the Center, and short-term tenants. The long-term producing organizations were also known as resident companies because they received funding from The Music Center and thus, had first choice of the available time in each of the theatres. In addition to sponsoring the free Symphonian Tours, the MCOC, through its archives, maintained a history of The Music Center from its inception.

Source: Music Center of L.A. County: Its History and Management document, Box 402, Folder 8, Music Center records (Collection 3261). UCLA Library Special Collections, Charles E. Young Research Library, University of California, Los Angeles.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Music Center Operating Company (MCOC) files range in date from 1949-2017 and contain Dorothy Chandler's photo albums, outfits, awards and memorabilia; Chandler's assistant Marian Burke's correspondence and transcripts; Music Center Building Fund documents; Music Center Lease Company minutes and correspondence; Performing Arts Council minutes; General Manager correspondence; Board of Directors minutes; booking and lease files; occupancy calendars; Production Department files; financial statements; Operating Committee minutes; Music Center Board of Governors minutes; strategic planning binders; Board of Governors subject files; complex and events files; complex photographs; master calendars; lease events photographs and slides; lease events files; ready reference files; Archives Manager files; Performing Arts Council bulletins; Music Center newsletters; press releases; National State County Partnership grant applications; MCOC-The Music Center merger files; Dedication Week and anniversary materials; Ahmanson Theatre reconfiguration documents; Pavilion and Performing Arts programs; Lease Events programs; The Symphonians President's notebooks; Speaker's Bureau binders; Irene Diener materials; usher uniforms; ephemera; artwork; digital and audiovisual materials.

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
phystech.p: CONTAINS UNPROCESSED AUDIO MATERIALS: Audio materials are not currently available for access and will require further processing and assessment. If you have questions about this material please email spec-coll@library.ucla.edu.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This box contains Hollywood Bowl items including documentation of the Van Cliburn benefit concerts, Dorothy Chandler's personal Bible, Performing Arts Council (PAC) Opportunity Fund correspondence, Pavilion Week Dedication programs, reports, invitations, 1964 December 18 Time Magazine which features Dorothy Buffum Chandler's portrait on the Building the Pavilions of Culture cover, Blue Ribbon Committee invitation, and a guest list for the Founders Reception and Dinner with Richard and Pat Nixon. Folder 10 contains one L.A. Music Center vinyl record composed by Tommy Thompson.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This box contains Music Center Operating Company (MCOC), PAC, and MC Unified Fund stationery, a Jacques Lipchitz lithograph record book, a Story Books ledger, clippings, "The Music Center Story" by Nancy Weakly, and Chandler's Board of Governors 1990 campaign book.

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
phystech.p: CONTAINS UNPROCESSED DIGITAL MATERIALS: Digital materials are not currently available for access and will require further processing and assessment. If you have questions about this material please email spec-coll@library.ucla.edu.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This box contains Los Angeles Times photographs of Dorothy Chandler at Music Center functions such as The Eldorado Party, a party with Pat and Richard Nixon, a signed color photograph of Dorothy Chandler and Zubin Mehta, inscribed by Mehta, contact prints with Princess Margaret, and digital photo documentation. Events and persons included are the opening of the Music Center, Save the Hollywood Bowl, Gregory Peck, the Oscars, the Buck Bag campaign, Frank Sinatra, and the Philharmonic. Folder 11 contains Dorothy Chandler's 132nd Negro Press Anniversary Award. Folder 8 contains six CDs of Dorothy Chandler photographs.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This box contains Blue Ribbon history booklets, programs, and invitations, the Dorothy Buffum Chandler Collection catalogue, clippings, Dorothy Chandler's Music Center Board of Governors meeting binder and reference book, Music Center Opera yearbook, Daughters of the American Revolution Award of Merit, and copies of Dorothy Chandler's obituaries. Folder 11 contains a Chandler Children's Festival 2001 audiocassette. Folder 14 contains one Inventing LA The Chandlers and Their Times DVD.

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
phystech.p: CONTAINS UNPROCESSED AND PROCESSED AUDIOVISUAL MATERIALS: The audiocassette is not currently available for access and will require further processing and assessment. The DVD is available for access. All requests to access audiovisual materials must be made in advance using the request button located on this page. If you have questions about this material please email spec-coll@library.ucla.edu.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This box contains photographs of Dorothy Chandler at the Hollywood Bowl, at the Pavilion, and presenting and receiving awards. This box also contains a William Severns Spirit of Los Angeles Award program, a Music Center Memories Otto Rothschild photo scrapbook, Times Mirror Company Resolution of Honor, and a framed recognition for the Performing Arts Council's contribution to the 1984 Olympics.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Otto Rothschild was a Los Angeles commercial photographer whose accounts included Kodak, U.S. Steel, Reynolds Aluminum, Carnation, Phillips, Standard Oil, Transamerica, and both the Republican and Democratic parties. Rothschild also served as the official house photographer for The Music Center, the Civic Light Opera, Hollywood Bowl, and the Los Angeles Philharmonic Orchestra. Rothschild held executive positions with the Los Angeles Press Photographers Association for decades and in 1969 he was honored with a life membership to the National Press Photographers Association, in recognition of his significant contributions to the cause of photography.

Source: Top O' The Mall III, no. 9 (September 1970), Boxes 736-737, Music Center records (Collection 3261). UCLA Library Special Collections, Charles E. Young Research Library, University of California, Los Angeles.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Otto Rothschild files range in date from 1930-2004 and contain biographical materials; Hollywood Bowl identification files; numeric negative identification files; alphanumeric negative identification files; 4x5" negatives; 4x5" nitrate negatives; 120mm negatives; 35mm negatives; 4x5" proof prints; contact sheets; 8x10 prints; oversize prints; slides; oversize slides; and a poster.

did.unittitle: Series 3: Los Angeles Philharmonic Orchestra files

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
phystech.p: CONTAINS UNPROCESSED DIGITAL, AUDIO, AND AUDIOVISUAL MATERIALS: Digital, audio, and audiovisual materials are not currently available for access and will require further processing and assessment. If you have questions about this material please email spec-coll@library.ucla.edu.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Founded by William Andrews Clark, Jr., a 42-year-old amateur musician, lawyer, bibliophile, and art patron, the Los Angeles Philharmonic Orchestra (LAPO) performed its first concert on Friday, October 24, 1919, in Trinity Auditorium with its first Music Director, Walter Henry Rothwell. For 15 years, Clark was the sole guarantor for the Orchestra, but the non-profit Southern California Symphony Association was organized shortly before his death in 1934 to assure continued sponsorship of the Orchestra. The Philharmonic was largely responsible for the "Symphonies Under the Stars" at the Hollywood Bowl. In 1921, the Orchestra played a program for an Easter Sunrise Service at the Bowl. A similar program in 1922 led to the founding of the summer symphony concerts, which began in July of 1922 and established the Hollywood Bowl as the summer home for the Philharmonic. The Los Angeles Philharmonic Orchestra performed its winter season concerts at the Philharmonic Auditorium from 1920 through the end of the 1963/1964 season. In 1964, the Orchestra moved to the Dorothy Chandler Pavilion where it performed until 2003, when it moved to the Walt Disney Concert Hall. After the 1927 departure of its first Music Director, Walter Henry Rothwell, ten conductors have served in that capacity: Georg Schnevoigt (19271929), Artur Rodziski (19291933), Otto Klemperer (19331939), Alfred Wallenstein (19431956), Eduard van Beinum (19561959), Zubin Mehta (19621978), Carlo Maria Giulini (19781984), Andr Previn (19851989), Esa-Pekka Salonen (19922009), and Gustavo Dudamel (2009present).

Source: Los Angeles Philharmonic Fact Sheet and History of the Los Angeles Philharmonic documents, Box 1,084, Music Center records (Collection 3261). UCLA Library Special Collections, Charles E. Young Research Library, University of California, Los Angeles.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Los Angeles Philharmonic Orchestra (LAPO) files range in date from 1909-2010 and contain LAPO bound programs; The Philharmonic Review; Magazine of Celebrities; season files; L.E. Behymer and Olga J. Rosenthal photographs; Philharmonic Auditorium files; The Evening Concert KFAC programs; Southern California Symphony Association programs; correspondence; publications; repertoire lists; clippings; compositions performed lists; LAPO photographs; Glendale Symphony Orchestra season files; International Musician journal; Los Angeles Symphony Orchestra programs; LAPO oversize photographs; posters; audio and audiovisual materials.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: A group of civic-minded women and men who were active in the area's artistic and business communities combined their efforts to establish the Hollywood Bowl and its summer music festival. The Bowl's founders wished to establish an outdoor park and art center to entertain and educate a large audience and build community spirit in the small town of Hollywood. Only around 5,000 people lived in Hollywood in 1910. On August 12, 1918, this group scheduled a meeting which resulted in the organization of the Theatre Arts Alliance. The Alliance incorporated on May 25, 1919 and in 1920 reorganized as the Community Park and Art Association. By 1920 the growth of the movie industry had turned this community into a boom-town, with a population close to 50,000. The Association's secretary, Mrs. Artie Mason Carter, was the most active in promoting the project to the community, raising money, and developing plans for a series of symphonic concerts. In fact, the permanent relationship between Hollywood Bowl and the Los Angeles Philharmonic Orchestra began when the orchestra's founder, William Andrews Clark, Jr., agreed to Carter's request that he donate the orchestra's services for the 1921 Easter Sunrise Service. Carter is sometimes referred to as the "mother of the Bowl." The Women's World Peace Concert, held on November 11, 1921 (Armistice Day), was one of the first major events at the Bowl, and on July 11, 1922, Alfred Hertz conducted the Los Angeles Philharmonic Orchestra in the first concert of the first season of "Symphonies Under the Stars."
Source: Hollywood Bowl Souvenir Book. Los Angeles: Los Angeles Philharmonic Association, 2000.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Hollywood Bowl files range in date from 1920-2014 and contain bound programs; history files; memorabilia; files of Florence Atherton Irish, known to most as Mrs. Leiland Atherton Irish, who was a co-founder of the Hollywood Bowl and served as its Director for almost thirty years; season files; Hollywood Bowl Association files; photograph files; negative files; Pilgrimage Play files, photographs, memorabilia; and audiovisual materials.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Edwin Lester was an American theatre director, impresario, and producer. He was the longtime general director of the Los Angeles Civic Light Opera (LACLO), which he founded in 1938. He also co-founded the LACLO's affiliate organization, the San Francisco Civic Light Opera (CLO), with Homer Curran in 1939.
Source: Organizational history files, Box 1,192, Music Center records (Collection 3261). UCLA Library Special Collections, Charles E. Young Research Library, University of California, Los Angeles.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Los Angeles Civic Light Opera files range in date from 1935-1998 and contain organizational history files; scripts and prompt books; season files; programs; scrapbooks; ad books; public relations files; San Francisco Civic Light Opera (CLO) ad books and programs; accounts payable files, window cards, photograph identification files; negatives; photographs; contact sheets; slides; Kenn Randall photographs; awards; proclamations; audio; and audiovisual materials.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This box contains biographical information on Edwin Lester, organizational history of the LACLO, an inventory of his collection, an inventory of window cards, audition lists, clippings, obituaries, Lester tribute books, and production ephemera.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The Music Center of Los Angeles County opened when the Dorothy Chandler Pavilion raised its curtain for the first time on December 6, 1964 with Zubin Mehta conducting the Los Angeles Philharmonic with soloist Jascha Heifetz. Construction began on the Pavilion on March 9, 1962 and the site was dedicated on September 27, 1964. The Pavilion has hosted opera performances, dance presentations, and the Academy Awards.

Sources: "Music Center of LA County -- Its History and Management", Box 402, Folder 8, Music Center records (Collection 3261). UCLA Library Special Collections, Charles E. Young Research Library, University of California, Los Angeles. The Music Center Fact Sheet, August 16, 1990.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Dorothy Chandler Pavilion files range in date from 1858-2017 and contain Libretti and Mason Opera House programs; Grand Opera House and Park Theatre programs; Los Angeles and San Francisco Theatre programs; Los Angeles Opera Association and Theatre programs; The Footlights Burbank Theatre programs; Music Center Opera season files; Music Center Opera Association programs, correspondence, business files, press releases, financial statements, paid invoices, and cash receipts; New York City Opera sales reports, tearsheets, clippings, season, publicity, and business files; Los Angeles Music Center Opera programs; New York City Opera biographies, photographs and season files; Music Center Opera Association Gala attendees index cards and files; Music Center Opera Association business files; Los Angeles Opera season files; LA Opera publicity files; Music Center Opera Association films; LA Opera audiovisual materials; Pat Martin materials; LA Opera window cards, awards, and posters; Joffrey Ballet clippings, correspondence, photographs, programs, historical files, and season files; International, classical, and folk ballet programs; Sadler's Wells and The Royal Ballet programs; Music Center Dance Presentations financial statements, ledgers, event logs, cash receipts, and invoices; Dance Association Newsletter; Dance press clippings; International Dance Salute files; Music Center Dance Association correspondence, photographs, and clippings; Center Dance Association photograph albums, ephemera, and publicity files; Glorya Kaufman Presents Dance at the Music Center season and publicity files; Alvin Ailey Revelations mounted photographs; Dwana Adiaha Smallwood photograph; dance audio and audiovisual materials; Joffrey Ballet, Glorya Kaufman Presents Dance at the Music Center, Dorothy Chandler Pavilion, and dance window cards; Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater posters; Academy Awards files; and Dorothy Chandler Pavilion posters, resolutions, and ephemera.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: On March 20, 1966, Dorothy Buffum Chandler, president of the Performing Arts Council of the Music Center, announced the Center Theatre Group (CTG) as the resident professional dramatic company of the Music Center. This announcement followed an agreement that the Theatre Group under managing director Gordon Davidson would move from UCLA to the Music Center. The formation of the Theatre Group under the auspices of the University of California Extension grew out of a conference of 100 academics and theater professionals from across the country held at Lake Arrowhead in 1958. The CTG presents performances at the Mark Taper Forum and the Ahmanson Theatre, both of which were dedicated on April 12, 1967. The Mark Taper Forum opened on April 9, 1967 with "The Devils," starring Frank Langella and Ed Flanders. The Ahmanson Theatre opened on September 12, 1967 with "More Stately Mansions" starring Ingrid Bergman, Arthur Hill, and Colleen Dewhurst.

Sources: "Theater Group Named Resident of Music Center," Los Angeles Times, March 20, 1966, Mark Taper Forum and Ahmanson Theatre dedication week files, Box 1,623, Music Center records (Collection 3261). UCLA Library Special Collections, Charles E. Young Research Library, University of California, Los Angeles. The Music Center Fact Sheet, August 1, 1990.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Center Theatre Group files range in date from 1732-2010 and contain Mark Taper Forum programs, season files, season binders, season photographs, and season index cards; Ahmanson Theatre season index cards, season files, photograph index cards, photographs, negatives, slides, window cards, and press files; Ahmanson Theatre at the UCLA James A. Doolittle Theater window cards; Walter Douglas scrapbooks; Mark Taper Forum renovation brochures, agreement, book, and correspondence, pins, reports, and photographs; Mark Taper Forum ephemera, window cards, and architectural blueprints; Mark Taper Forum and Ahmanson Theatre dedication week files; Center Theatre Group audio and audiovisual materials; Kenn Randall early LA theater survey, prompt books, theatre programs, and photographs; Raymond F. Barnes theatre history index cards, LA, NY, and Chicago Legit records, LA vaudeville records, LA theatre programs, Biltmore Theatre programs, Pasadena Playhouse programs, Shrine Auditorium programs, Greek Theatre programs and reviews, Huntington Hartford Theatre programs and reviews, theatre playbill scrapbooks, photographs, and posters; George Zoritch Playbill magazines, photographs, correspondence, programs, and posters; Olga Rosenthal correspondence and New York City Opera photographs; Leiland A. Irish Overture magazines, sheet music, and LA theatre history data; Charles Coburn drama publications and sheet music; and music manuscripts.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: On June 26, 1968, Music Center founder, Dorothy Buffum Chandler, convened an afternoon reception of 27 women in Los Angeles at the home of Virginia Ramo. After tea, sandwiches, and cakes, Chandler announced that she was organizing the Blue Ribbon 400: Blue Ribbon because she liked the name she had given to a committee of women to raise the final $1 million of private funding needed to build the Music Center complex in 1963; and 400 because once the membership reached that number, it would be closed. Blue Ribbon members paid dues, planned, and sponsored the Music Center's social, educational, and cultural activities.

Blue Ribbon member financial contributions would go to what is now the annual Music Center Unified Fund campaign, which provides support for all the Music Center resident companies: The Los Angeles Philharmonic, Center Theatre Group, Joffrey Ballet, the Los Angeles Music Center Opera, and the Los Angeles Master Chorale.

Founded in 1976, Club 100 includes more than 100 women who support the performing arts through education, advocacy, and fundraising. The purpose of Club 100 is to train its members and other Music Center volunteer groups to be effective fundraisers for the Music Center Unified Fund and leading volunteers for the Music Center. Club 100's membership contributes more than $500,000 annually to the Center and sponsors the Distinguished Artist Award to honor members of the artistic community.

Founded in 1978 by Thornton Bradshaw, Charles T. Manatt, and other Music Center supporters, the Fraternity of Friends is a group of businessmen and entertainment industry executives who share a common interest in the performing arts and believe that the well-being of the Center is directly linked to the betterment of Los Angeles. The Fraternity of Friends' combined membership contributes more than $500,000 annually to the Center.
LA Alive! is an annual, free, two-day arts festival that celebrates the ethnic diversity of Los Angeles.

Sources: "The Blue Ribbon Story" researched and written by Betty Goodwin, Box 1,815, Center records (Collection 3261). UCLA Library Special Collections, Charles E. Young Research Library, University of California, Los Angeles. By-Laws of Club 100, Box 1825, Music Center records (Collection 3261). UCLA Library Special Collections, Charles E. Young Research Library, University of California, Los Angeles. "Fraternity of Friends" informational sheet, Box 1850, Music Center records (Collection 3261). UCLA Library Special Collections, Charles E. Young Research Library, University of California, Los Angeles. The Music Center Fact Sheet, August 1, 1990. "Performing Arts Center of Los Angeles County", Box 402, Folder 8, Music Center records (Collection 3261). UCLA Library Special Collections, Charles E. Young Research Library, University of California, Los Angeles.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The Music Center Education Division (MCED) was founded in 1979 to support a positive and dynamic future for the Music Center by engaging people with the arts -- at the Center, in schools and in communities -- and to provide leadership to advance the quality and scope of arts education in Southern California. The Education Division is committed to the belief that experiencing the arts enhances the quality of life for all people, and is a crucial part of the development of every child. Each year MCED presents performances and other arts programs in hundreds of public and private schools with a full spectrum of arts experiences to nurture the creative potential in students and teachers and to develop future artists, informed audiences, and dedicated arts supporters. The Division's varied programs offer a distinguished roster of artists representing diverse cultures, disciplines, and styles.

Source: Music Center Performing Arts Center of Los Angeles County press kit, Music Center Education Division, Box 1,964, Music Center records (Collection 3261). UCLA Library Special Collections, Charles E. Young Research Library, University of California, Los Angeles.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The Music Center of Los Angeles County opened its newest venue, the Frank Gehry-designed Walt Disney Concert Hall (WDCH) in October 2003, expanding the existing Music Center campus to 11 acres. The Hall is the home of the Los Angeles Philharmonic and the Los Angeles Master Chorale. Located on a historic downtown Los Angeles site, Walt Disney Concert Hall is situated on Bunker Hill at the intersection of First Street and Grand Avenue, adjacent to the Dorothy Chandler Pavilion. A large portion of the site is devoted to an urban public park that is accessible not only from the Hall, but from the adjacent streets. The primary entry plaza, located at the corner of First and Grand, connects the facility to the existing Music Center Plaza, and a secondary entry plaza, located at the corner of 2nd and Grand, provides primary access to the gardens.

Source: Music Center Performing Arts Center of Los Angeles County press kit, Backgrounder Walt Disney Concert Hall, Box 1,964, Music Center records (Collection 3261). UCLA Library Special Collections, Charles E. Young Research Library, University of California, Los Angeles.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Walt Disney Concert Hall (WDCH) files range in date from 1974-2012 and contain Task Force notes and studies; historic files and clippings; community gifts binders; committee binder and authorization book; Capital Campaign binders; Opening binder and press kits; Corporate records books; Master Agreement and Communications binders; Marketing and Communications Department files; project files, photographs, and reports; Board Authorization Book and Program draft; sublease agreement drafts; project files; legal files; Gershwin Gallery files; Speaker Series photographs, ephemera, and audiovisual materials; graphic presentations; cafe, Pavilion plans, and presentations; interior plans, exterior models, and restaurant renderings; Collar and Bow, projection images, and Wayfinding Graphics; posters, plans, and renderings; Grand Avenue Pedestrian Project plans; Dedication ephemera and memorabilia; Civic Opening kit and Frank O. Gehry photograph; Dedication guest books; hard hat and memorabilia; Urban Land Institute Award for Excellence; audiovisual materials; construction slides; Dedication Report; and digital materials.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Books from the Music Center's Reference Library that were originally donated with the records have been individually cataloged in the UCLA Library online catalog. Records for these items may be found by searching the Special Coll/Archive SPAC "MCOC" using the Advanced search tab in the Library catalog, or keyword searching "Books from the Music Center Reference Library".

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The Music Center Reference Library comprises approximately 450 volumes of predominantly theatrical subjects built by patron gifts to the Music Center and through purchases by archivists. These monographs have accession numbers and there is an author/title index card catalog. The library also contains a music reference collection of approximately 100 titles, a dance reference collection of approximately 35 titles, monographs from Dorothy Buffum Chandler's personal library, as well as publications from Chandler's assistant Marian Burke's personal library. There is also a small collection of periodicals in the Reference Library acquired through Music Center funds.

Source: Assessment of the Collections and Services of the Los Angeles Music Center Operating Company Archives, a report prepared by Michael A. Keller, Music Consultant and Head of the Music Library, University of California at Berkeley, Box 509, Folder 6, Music Center records (Collection 3261). UCLA Library Special Collections, Charles E. Young Research Library, University of California, Los Angeles.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Music Center Reference Library ranges in date from 1872-2018 and contains a Reference Library index card catalog; monographs; Notes: The Quarterly Journal of the Music Library Association; Theatre Arts Monthly; New York Theatre Critics' Reviews; Annals of the New York Stage; High Performance; Musical America; and Stage.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This box also contains accession cards.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This box also contains a handwritten index and related correspondence from former Music Center archivists.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Music Center memorabilia and ephemera ranges in date from 1919-2018 and contains window card inventories; LAPO, Lease events, Mark Taper Forum, Ahmanson Theatre, and Music Center Opera Association New York City Opera window cards; oversize posters; Music Center, Center Theatre Group, Glorya Kaufman Presents Dance at the Music Center, Hollywood Bowl, Spotlight Awards ephemera; WDCH, and LA Opera ephemera; oversize Otto Rothschild photographs; Black Business Dance at the Music Center resolutions; Dorothy Chandler diploma and awards; Charles A. Buffum portrait; Buff Chandler portrait by Henry Koerner; and a Dorothy Chandler arts and education bell.
